è°èƒ½æƒ³åˆ°æˆ‘ä¸€ä»‹æ–‡ç›²ä¸ºäº†ç©ä¸€ä¸ªç†å·¥ç§‘æ¸¸æˆ...ç‰¹åœ°å»æ‰“å°åº—æŠŠ"é€ƒç”Ÿèˆ±æŠ€æœ¯æ‰‹å†Œ"æ‰“äº†ä¸€ä»½å½©è‰²è¿‡å¡‘æ–‡æ¡£å‡ºæ¥å±…ç„¶æ¯”æ¸¸æˆè¿˜è´µ

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 30 octobre 2020
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

Tin Can is basically a simulation of how every IT guy imagines he's going to die.
 
Grimtoast
5
417 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
5 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
26
RecommandÃ©
2.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 13 mai 2022
EDIT: Changed this to a "recommend," though i still wouldn't "recommend" it. I just don't appreciate Steam turning a lack of endorsement into a full on condemnation.
--------

If you were thinking of The Martian, Gravity, or Apollo 13... Put those out of your head, they couldn't be farther from this in tone. This is not a survival simulator or a troubleshooting simulator. This is not decision driven. This is not a game about prioritizing your needs and making decisions about what you can and can't do without.

This is 30 minutes of panicked plate spinning.

Every system in the ship will fail, and the challenge isn't about prioritization or diagnostics or resource management but pure speed. As another review said, if you ever have to consult the manual you've already lost.

Speaking of the manual, that hints at my major complaint about the game. The information in the manual is extremely limited and poorly organized, not at all how the real thing would be. There are no system diagrams, no diagnostic flowcharts, no checklists, no quick reference of any kind. Just pages of disorganized error codes and part descriptions.

The various gauges too seem to be designed to give as little information in a glance as possible, and are not at all designed as their real counterparts would be. You could make the argument that it's bad design (and it is) or poorly researched, but this and the manual both strike me as intentional design choices to artificially increase difficulty and complexity. (It also communicates that you're living in a built-by-the-lowest-bidder hellworld of budget space exploration similar to Avenue 5, but the game itself barely seems aware of this which makes it both annoying and difficult to believe.)

There are only 2 systems that can safely be cannibalized to repair essential systems, and it's often easier to just immediately strip them for parts because they provide very little benefit, so there's not really any decision making there.

The repair station feel like it was designed for an entirely different game. It makes sense in a setting where you'd need to deliberate over which parts to keep and which to toss. It'd make sense if you were restocking your spare parts. But you won't even have enough time to load it with repair points before you need to make repairs to life threatening damage. And if a component from a vital system fails without backups available, you'll die before you even get close to repairing it with the station.

This is almost an amazing game. The bones are there. But this plays more like an early access balance test than a full game. The kind of release that is "feature complete" in the sense that checkers would be a "feature complete" prototype of chess. And like checkers it can be fun and worth playing, and this is pretty much the only game to have attempted this and certainly deserves credit for getting as close as it has.

But it's not "Realistic management of vital resources, such as oxygen, carbon dioxide, temperature and radiation" with "An onboard manual providing detailed information about your escape pod" or "Organic failures thanks to the simulated nature of resources and components inside the game", it's trying to keep every system running for 30 minutes in a neglected, poorly designed, and half disassembled pod with a useless manual and part failures caused randomly every few minutes by one of 5 random space weather events.
 
Un dÃ©veloppeur ou une dÃ©veloppeuse a rÃ©pondu Ã  cette Ã©valuation
fieryace
17
80 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
12
RecommandÃ©
11.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 24 avril 2021
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

Yeah, so in an odd way, this game is kinda horrifying. I don't often get a real feeling of "horror" from video games... even games that are "supposed to be" terrifying. And maybe it's just ME with this game - maybe others don't get this? I don't know? - but this game very often creeps the heck out of me. (At the same time, it scratches a bunch of other video game itches as well, such as solving several problems at once on the fly, making fast and critical decisions, etc.)

So for whatever reason - maybe the ship is failing, maybe it's been in a battle, who knows - you find yourself in an escape pod out in deep space. You close the hatch and lock it, and your pod shoots out into space. Great - now, if this were every scifi movie ever, you'd sit back, worry about your friends in the other pods, maybe play some chess on the computer, and wait out the ride until you landed on some distant planet, and THEN your real dangerous journey would begin, right? Or maybe you'd just go into cryosleep and be found 500 years later and get into some wacky adventure.

In Tin Can, you're in an escape pod that... well, really isn't much better than a tin can. This thing is loaded with systems and subsystems that are practically as delicate as paper, it seems. At first, you'll be taking care of some very basic, routine stuff... Make sure everything is set up the way you want it, make sure oxygen bottle is full and CO2 bottle empty, etc. Maybe pull a few components out that you know you'll be using for other things later, or swap things around a little.

However, whatever system shot you out into space seems to have intentionally aimed you at every possible hazard out there. You're going to find your little pod flying through asteroid fields (BAM!!! Everything you're holding gets knocked to the ground, and oh no, HULL BREACH!!), ice nebulae or close star fly-by's (extremes of temperature - PREPARE APPROPRIATELY!), "lightning storms" (which can fry EVERYTHING on your little pod), gravitational upsets, and more.

One by one, your systems begin to fail. Maybe it's not so bad at first - maybe an alarm light gets broken, or maybe a monitor starts to flicker. Maybe a fuse goes bad. You do what you can - maybe you're not worried about that particular component, or maybe you go ahead and make repairs. Maybe you start cannibalizing other systems to support your more vital ones. Maybe you decide to take risks - I'll pull the fuse out of that system and run it without a fuse - which will allow it to work, but also subject it to potential damage due to electrical surges.

As more and more time passes, your systems get more and more damaged. At this point you're chucking parts around, deciding that this or that system is now a total loss, and that you have to do whatever it takes to keep your atmo or temp systems running. Your heart will stop as a particularly bad lightning flash knocks out your reactor - and you'll pray you'll be able to get it started again. You'll feel building panic as one of your life support systems begins to get harder and harder to restart. You'll be overcome by a sense of dread as the lights flicker out... and the emergency lights don't come on. Or maybe as you grab hand-holds to get around... because your artificial gravity system is now destroyed.

Your character responds to all of these hazards accordingly. If you're freezing to death, your field of view will slowly crowd with a sort of icy haze.. If you're dying because of asphyxiation or carbon dioxide poisoning, you'll hear yourself panting for breath as your vision gets all blurred and hazy. You'll hear yourself rasping raggedly as you're cooking alive... hear the buzz of electricity as you fry yourself, and much more.

Why the opening lines of my review? Talking about horror and a sense of dread? You've just spent like twenty minutes fighting to keep your little ship running. Warning lights are flashing and alarms are buzzing right and left. Sparks are flying out of instrument cabinets. Maybe air is escaping into space due to a hull breach. The temperature regulators are failing, as are your air systems. You've got like three different systems you're trying to work on, and then your reactor fails entirely, and the battery in your emergency lights cabinet is dead (couldn't get to it fast enough, maybe). You're now literally just in a can. There's nothing regulating your temperature, no systems to keep your air breathable, nothing to nail you to the floor, and no light. You run out your suit's internal battery with your flashlight as you desperately try to accomplish ten things at once - you've got to get batteries into your critical systems just to survive, and you've GOT to find a way to get that reactor started back up!! You've GOT to find a way to get the repair system working so you can diagnose the parts of your reactor!

At that point... deep inside, you know everything you're doing is futile. You know that within minutes or less, you will die. How will it be? Hypothermia? Will you cook alive? Will you die poisoned by your own carbon dioxide? How will you die? But for some reason, you keep fighting - LOOK! I got the CO2 scrubber restarted on battery power!!! Now I just need to get that O2 system running to buy myself another couple minutes... but by then will I have even made a dent in the reactor...? Meanwhile your suit's battery keeps running out, so you keep turning on the flashlight, just to have it go out moments later...

The fight to survive in this game is real. Can you get a place on the leaderboard? Go for it.. and good luck.

Yeah I like this one.
 
jupiter darmin
0
248 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
5 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
30
Non recommandÃ©
0.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 13 mai 2022
TL;DR, this game is great if you:
- have a fantastic memory
- enjoy a frantic pace, without time to think
- like the feeling of "just scraping by" on the skin of your teeth
- want to replay similar sequences many times to compete for high scores

I don't check any of these boxes, so for me and people like me, this is a hard no.

Don't be fooled by the written descriptions or by the demo/tutorial into thinking this game is about thoughtful troubleshooting and problem solving. This game is about speed, first and foremost. It is meant to be replayed many times, such that you memorize your manual and the interactions of systems on the escape pod, and you can compete for the longest survival time on the hardcore mode without needing time to think.

If you are not like me, and that sounds appealing to you, go for it.

Full thoughts:

I played the tutorial and was interested in the game. Once I got into the full game and saw the game modes began with "Survive 6 minutes," I was skeptical - when the game threw me into a fiery inferno where I had 1 minute to try to collect as many items as possible before getting into the escape pod, without knowing the value any of those items would have in my journey, I knew the game would not be for me.

As I pressed onward to find that the escape pod wasn't even fully assembled to start with, my feeling was reaffirmed.

What I was hoping for: A fully functional escape pod with insufficient extra parts, where the systems would slowly deteriorate (or suddenly fail) over the course of at least 30 minutes. Varying intensity, with quiet periods spent in contemplative dread, considering what could go wrong next and how to prepare for it, as well as periods of high intensity, "everything is on fire" gameplay, and a spectrum in between.

What I got (in my opinion): A "60 Seconds!" inspired opening sequence of frantically collecting everything you can click on, followed by frantically realizing vital components of the escape pod were already missing so trying to have a fully functional escape pod was hopeless, followed by 6 minutes of frantically trying to read an obtuse manual, scrolling down to what I was looking for, forgetting exactly what page it was on, scrolling back up, then back down, then finally finding something I could fix, (repeat that a few times), then finding something wrong that I didn't have parts for, and just watching the clock tick down wondering if I would die or not.

I did, in fact, survive 6 minutes, but with nary a moment to thoughtfully consider my predicament or how to best solve it, and actually very little troubleshooting involved. The "troubleshooting" of the game appears to be mainly relegated to interpreting error codes through a manual that is miserable to use. Some error codes appear to have multiple possible causes, so ostensibly there may be some troubleshooting to do in longer scenarios, but I don't believe the game provides the necessary breathing room to approach that troubleshooting thoughtfully and intentionally. Ultimately, I requested a refund.

I would love to see a similar game with a much longer, deeper, more complex gameplay loop, designed for hours rather than minutes, and which encourages the player to slow down and think.

æ…¢æ…¢çš„ï¼Œä½ çš„é€ƒç”Ÿèˆ±ä¼šéšç€æ—¶é—´æµé€å¼€å§‹é€æ¸å‡ºç°æ•…éšœï¼Œåœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œå«å¤©å¤©ä¸çµï¼Œå«åœ°åœ°ä¸åº”ï¼Œåæ­£æ€»æ˜¯ä¼šæ­»çš„ï¼Œåªä¸è¿‡æ˜¯æ—¶é—´é—®é¢˜ç½¢äº†ã€‚

ä¸€å¼€å§‹ä¸ä¼šç‰¹åˆ«ç³Ÿç³•ï¼Œè­¦æŠ¥å™¨åäº†ï¼Œè¡¥ä¸€ä¸‹å°±å¥½ï¼Œæ˜¾ç¤ºå™¨å¼€å§‹é—ªçƒäº†ï¼Œé‡æ–°æ¥ä¸‹çº¿è°ƒæ•´ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œä¿é™©ä¸çƒ§äº†ï¼Œæ¢ä¸€ä¸‹å°±æ˜¯ã€‚å°½è‡ªå·±æ‰€èƒ½ä¿®ä¿®è¡¥è¡¥ï¼ŒåŸºæœ¬ä¸ç”¨å»æ‹…å¿ƒæŸäº›ç‰¹å®šçš„ç»„ä»¶ï¼Œåœ¨ä¿®ç†çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œä½†è¿™äº›å¼±å°çš„éšæ‚£å®ƒä¼šæ…¢æ…¢çš„èš•é£Ÿä½ çš„æ ¸å¿ƒç³»ç»Ÿã€‚æˆ‘æ›¾æƒ³è¿‡ï¼Œå¦‚æœåœ¨æŸä¸ªçœ‹èµ·æ¥ä¸é‡è¦çš„éƒ¨ä»¶ä¸­æ‹†èµ°ä¿é™©ä¸ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”ä¸ç”¨ä¿é™©ä¸å»è¿›è¡Œè¿ä½œï¼Œä½†å®é™…æƒ…å†µè¿™æ ·å°±æœ‰å¯èƒ½ä¼šå‘ç”Ÿæ¼ç”µçš„æ½œåœ¨æŸå®³ã€‚

éšç€æ—¶é—´æµé€ï¼Œé€ƒç”Ÿèˆ±ä¸­çš„ç³»ç»Ÿä¼šå—åˆ°è¶Šæ¥è¶Šå¤šçš„æŸåï¼Œåœ¨è¿™ä¸ªæƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œå°±ä¼šå‡ºç°å››å¤„ä¸¢é›¶ä»¶çš„ç°è±¡äº†ï¼ˆåæ­£æˆ‘å°±æ˜¯ï¼‰ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¦å¿«é€Ÿæ‰¾å‡ºæ¥ç©¶ç«Ÿæ˜¯å“ªä¸ªåœ°æ–¹å‡ºç°äº†é—®é¢˜ï¼Œåœ¨æ‰¾é—®é¢˜çš„åŒæ—¶è¦ä¿æŒç©ºæ°”å’Œæ¸©åº¦ç³»ç»Ÿæ­£å¸¸è¿è¡Œï¼Œå®‡å®™çš„éšæœºäº‹ä»¶ä¹Ÿä¼šéšæ—¶å–èµ°ä½ çš„ç‹—å‘½ï¼Œä¸å°å¿ƒè¢«æ‰“ä¸­äº†ååº”å †æ—¶ï¼Œç”Ÿå‘½æ”¯æŒç³»ç»Ÿä¼šå˜å¾—éš¾ä»¥é‡æ–°å¯åŠ¨ï¼Œè¿™æ—¶èƒ½æ¸…æ™°æ„Ÿè§‰åˆ°è§’è‰²æ„Ÿåˆ°ææ…Œã€ç¯å…‰é—ªçƒæ—¶ä¼šè¢«å³å°†æ­»äº¡çš„ææƒ§æ„Ÿæ‰€å‹å€’ã€‚

è§’è‰²ä¼šç›¸åº”ç¢°è§å®‡å®™ä¸­çš„éšæœºäº‹ä»¶ï¼Œå¦‚æœè¢«å†»æ­»äº†ï¼Œè§†é‡ä¼šæ…¢æ…¢å……æ»¡å†°å†·çš„é›¾éœ¾ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ°§æ°”ä¸è¶³å¯¼è‡´çª’æ¯æˆ–è€…äºŒæ°§åŒ–ç¢³å¯¼è‡´ä¸­æ¯’è€Œå³å°†æ­»æ‰ï¼Œä¼šå¬è§å–˜ä¸ä¸Šæ°”çš„å£°éŸ³ï¼Œæ…¢æ…¢çš„è§†é‡ä¼šå˜å¾—æ¨¡ç³Šèµ·æ¥ï¼Œä¸æ¸…æ™°çš„å¬è§è‡ªå·±æ–¯æ–¯çš„å‘¼å¸å£°ï¼Œè„‘å­å—¡å—¡å«çš„å£°éŸ³ã€‚

è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆä¹‹æ‰€ä»¥éœ€è¦ä¸€å®šçš„å­¦ä¹ æ—¶é—´æˆæœ¬å’Œå¯¹ç†å·¥ä¿®ç†ç±»æœ‰ä¸€å®šçš„ç¡¬æ€§è¦æ±‚ï¼Œä»ç®€å•ç»´ä¿®æ¥ç»´æŒå°èˆ±çš„æ­£å¸¸è¿è½¬ï¼Œä»è­¦æŠ¥å™¨é—ªçƒâ†’è­¦æŠ¥å™¨å—¡å—¡ä½œå“ï¼Œç«èŠ±ä»ä»ªå™¨æŸœä¸­å†²å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œä¹Ÿæœ‰å¯èƒ½æ˜¯å› ä¸ºèˆ¹ä½“è¢«ç ´åäº†å‡ºç°æ¼æ´è®©ç©ºæ°”è¿›å…¥äº†å¤ªç©ºã€‚
æ¸©åº¦è°ƒèŠ‚å™¨æŸåäº†ï¼Œç©ºæ°”è°ƒèŠ‚ç³»ç»Ÿä¹Ÿå¤±çµäº†ï¼Œå°è¯•ä½¿ç”¨ä¸‰ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„ç³»ç»Ÿè¿›è¡ŒæŠ¢æ•‘ï¼Œè¿™æ—¶å€™ååº”å †åˆæ‰é“¾å­äº†ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰å¯èƒ½åº”æ€¥ç¯æŸœä¸­çš„ç”µæ± è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰ç”µã€‚
å°±åƒåœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªã€ç½å­ã€‘é‡Œé¢ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰ä»»ä½•ä¸œè¥¿å¯ä»¥è°ƒèŠ‚è‡ªèº«çš„æ¸©åº¦ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰ä»»ä½•ç³»ç»Ÿè¿›è¡Œç©ºæ°”è½¬æ¢ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰å…‰çº¿åˆ°å¤„æ˜¯é»‘æ¼†æ¼†çš„ï¼Œåœ¨è¿™ä¸ªæ—¶å€™ï¼Œç©¶ç«Ÿæ˜¯é€‰æ‹©è€å®ç­‰æ­»é‡å¼€è¿˜æ˜¯æƒ³æƒ³åŠæ³•æŠŠè‡ªå·±ç»™å¼ºè¡ŒæŠ¢æ•‘å›æ¥ã€‚

åœ¨é‚£ä¸ªæ—¶å€™ï¼Œæ‰€èƒ½çŸ¥é“çš„ï¼Œå†æ€ä¹ˆä½¿åŠ²æŠ˜è…¾éƒ½æ˜¯ã€å¾’åŠ³è€Œå·²ã€‘ï¼Œè¿˜ä¸å¦‚ç›´æ¥æ‘†çƒ‚ç­‰æ­»ï¼Œèƒ½è€—å‡ ç§’æ˜¯å‡ ç§’ï¼Œåˆ°æœ€åè‡ªå·±æ˜¯æ­»äºäºŒæ°§åŒ–ç¢³ä¸­æ¯’è¿˜æ˜¯æ°§æ°”ä¾›åº”ä¸è¶³çª’æ¯ï¼Œåœ¨è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆä¸­ä¹Ÿå­˜åœ¨æœ‰ã€ç”Ÿå­˜æ—¶é•¿ã€‘çš„æ’è¡Œæ¦œï¼Œæƒ³åœ¨æ’è¡Œä¸­å æœ‰ä¸€å¸­ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œå¾€å¾€æœ‰æ—¶å€™æƒ³æƒ³åŠæ³•æŠŠæŸäº›éƒ¨ä»¶ç»™å¼ºè¡Œæ•‘å›æ¥ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å°±èƒ½ç»™è‡ªå·±çš„å°å‘½ä¹°ä¸€äº›æ—¶é—´å›æ¥ï¼Œå½“ç„¶ç›´æ¥é€‰æ‹©ã€æ‘†çƒ‚ã€‘ç¡®å®æœ‰ç‚¹ä¸å¤ªå¥½ç©ï¼Œåœ¨ç”Ÿå‘½ä¸­å³å°†æ®†å°½çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå¼ºè¡Œåˆç»­å‘½äº†å›æ¥ï¼Œåº”è¯¥æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆæœ€å¤§çš„ä¹è¶£ã€‚ã€

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 11 mars 2023
While I thoroughly enjoyed the tin can, I bought it with the promise that Multiplayer would be added at some point, and proceeded to buy the game for a friend of mine for when multiplayer was eventually released. The option for multiplayer was greyed out in the main menu all throughout development, until right before release of 1.0, they just said â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ it can't be bothered, and released the game, and removed multiplayer from the main menu, no more mention of it happening since. They didn't even make it seem like a possibility that they were gonna remove multiplayer until the very end. Anyway, I am just not a fan of being lied to, so a thumbs down from me.

This was my review, although I would like to refer you to the developer response, as what I believe to be the correct way to handle negative feedback. I honestly am still enjoying the game for what it is, and I would have loved to recommend it in the original review, but I felt as though the developers just didn't really care. After the response, and also after having visited their discord to talk to the developers who are very active. I feel as though they have earned their 1.0 release, and my positive review.

Sehr coole Ãœberlebens-Simulation in einer Rettungskapsel alleine irgendwo im Orbit... Das Ziel: So lange zu Ã¼berleben, wie es geht... Mein erster Versuch dauerte nur 34 Minuten, dann bin ich aufgrund eines Generatorausfalls in meiner Kapsel erfroren...

Das einzige, was einem hilft, ist der Verstand und ein kleines Handbuch, in dem sÃ¤mtliche Module, aber auch Fehlercodes erklÃ¤rt werden (liegt ausgedruckt neben mir). Um einen herum eine kleine Rettungskapsel mit einigen Anzeigen und Schaltern. Schnell lernt man, dass man die O2- und die CO2-Flasche regelmÃ¤ÃŸig austauschen muss, bevor man erstickt. Auch die Luftfilter mÃ¼ssen regelmÃ¤ÃŸig gereinigt werden. Aber das bekommt man schon rechtzeitig mit, wenn Master Warning und Master Caution beginnen zu nerven. Auch die Temperatur, der Stromverbrauch und die Gravitation muss im Auge behalten werden.

SÃ¤mtliche Komponenten und Systeme hÃ¤ngen irgendwie zusammen. Sind alle Systeme im Normalbetrieb, ist alles ok. Aber schon das erste Asteroidenfeld macht einem ordentlich zu schaffen. Vom Eisnebel oder einer elektrostatischen Wolke will ich gar nicht erst reden... GlÃ¼ck gehabt, wenn nur ein kleiner Schalter kaputt ist, einfach austauschen und weiter geht's. Gehen grÃ¶ÃŸere Komponenten kaputt, kann man diese zwar reparieren, benÃ¶tigt dafÃ¼r aber entsprechend viel Strom. Ein Blick auf die Generatorleistung hilft bei der Entscheidung, ebenso wenn es um das Thema Licht geht. Notlicht verbraucht weniger Strom als volle Beleuchtung. Zum GlÃ¼ck habe ich eine Taschenlampe dabei.

Das Spiel mach sehr viel SpaÃŸ und kann auch im sog. Party-Modus gespielt werden, Ã¤hnlich wie bei "Keep Talking And Nobody Explodes" - einer ist in der Kapsel, der andere hat das Handbuch. Sehr spannend! ;-)

Das Spiel ist EA, lÃ¤uft aber flÃ¼ssig und ist gut spielbar, Bugs habe ich keine festgestellt. Ein kleines Tutorial wÃ¤re hilfreich, aber ich glaube, genau das will das Spiel ja gerade nicht, man soll als Laie versuchen zu Ã¼berleben. Die Tasten lassen sich momentan noch nicht frei belegen (nicht so schlimm, man braucht eh nur WSAD, F, Strg und Tab, der Rest geht mit der Maus) und die leise Hintergrundmusik kann man noch nicht abschalten. Aber das kommt sicherlich noch.

Daumen hoch und Kaufempfehlung fÃ¼r alle Survival-, RÃ¤tsel-, Raumfahrt- und Technikfreaks! :-)

RecommandÃ©
0.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 12 dÃ©cembre 2020
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

I ended up refunding this one, but it's not a bad game, just not really what I was looking for. When I purchased, I had thought it was a game that was more of a race against time to triage what part of your escape pod had failed and to swap it with spare parts or attempt to repair it.

What it actually is, is more of a puzzle/resource management game. You have a magic box that can tear down components for raw material or fix them. It's easy to tell what systems are failing and why, the actual challenge is in trying to juggle which parts you can strip out of your escape pod or juggle around to stay alive. I can absolutely understand why some people may like that sort of game, so I'm giving it a thumbs up here, even though it's not really for me.
 
Action Bastard!
1
67 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
7
Non recommandÃ©
4.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 28 octobre 2021
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

This sounded pretty promising, since I enjoy troubleshooting and fixing problems. The idea of complex systems gradually malfunctioning as you slowly drift through space in your escape pod seemed like good fun to me.

Unfortunately, there's nothing slow in this game. Within the first 15 minutes you have likely encountered a meteor storm, a sun, and a black hole, each requiring you to rush around fixing problems while simultaneously preparing for the next event. There are no breaks to consider what to do next or to catch up with things you didn't have time to do during the previous event.

To compensate for the rush, the escape pod systems are fairly simplistic. There's a degree of complexity and interconnectedness between the systems, but less than I had initially expected. There is a manual which allows you to look error codes up and read about the systems, but if you have to use it, you have already lost.

Even if you do enjoy the more rushed nature of the game, the limited number of random events (5 in total, a new one occurring every 5-10 minutes) means that you'll soon have seen everything the game has to offer.

That said, I do wish the developers the best of luck and hope that they'll consider a slower paced game mode which provides a longer term challenge.
 
Shiro

ã„ããªã‚Šãƒ—ãƒ­ã®å¨æˆ¿ã«èª¬æ˜ç„¡ã—ã§æ”¾ã‚Šè¾¼ã¾ã‚Œã¦ã€æ˜Ÿï¼•ã¤ãƒ¬ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ©ãƒ³ã®æ–™ç†ã‚’ï¼“ï¼åˆ†ã§ä½œã‚Œã¨è¨€ã‚ã‚Œã¦ã‚‹æ„Ÿã˜ã§ã™ã€‚

å¤§æŠµã®å ´åˆã¯ï¼”åˆ†ç¨‹åº¦ã§ä¸»é›»æºãŒä½•ã‚‰ã‹ã®æ•…éšœã‚’èµ·ã“ã—ã¦ãƒ—ãƒ¬ã‚¤ãƒ¤ãƒ¼ã¯æ®ºã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚
ãã‚Œã«å¯¾å‡¦ã™ã‚‹ç‚ºã«äºˆã‚éƒ¨å“ã‚’å„æ‰€ã‹ã‚‰æŠœãå–ã‚Šä¿®ç†ç®±ã«å…¥ã‚Œã‚‹ã®ã§ã™ãŒã€æ™‚é–“ã®ä½™è£•ã¯ï¼‘åˆ†ç¨‹åº¦ã—ã‹ãªã„ç‚ºã€ã‚ˆã»ã©æ‰‹æ…£ã‚Œã¦ã„ãªã„ã¨ç„¡ç†ã§ã™ã€‚

ä½•ã‚’ã™ã‚‹ã«ã—ã¦ã‚‚æ™‚é–“ãŒç„¡ã„ã—ä½•ã‚’ã™ã‚‹ã«ã—ã¦ã‚‚æ“ä½œæ€§ãŒæ‚ªãã€ã¾ãŸæ•…éšœãŒåˆ†ã‹ã£ãŸã¨ã—ã¦ã‚‚ä¿®ç†ã§ããªã„æ™‚ã¯çµ¶æœ›ã—ãªãŒã‚‰å‚è¦³ã™ã‚‹ã—ã‹ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚
ã“ã®å½“ãŸã‚Šã¯ã‚µãƒã‚¤ãƒãƒ«ç‰©ã§é£Ÿæ–™ãŒç„¡ããªã‚‹ã¨ã‹å¯’æ³¢ç†±æ³¢ã«å¯¾å‡¦å‡ºæ¥ãªã„ã¨ã‹ã®æ„Ÿè¦šã«ä¼¼ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

çµå±€ã€æ„Ÿé›»ã—ãªã„ç‚ºã«ä¸»é›»æºã‚’åˆ‡ã‚‹ã¨ã‹ã€ä¸»é›»æºã‚’æ´»ã‹ã™ç‚ºã«ä»–ã®è£…ç½®ã‹ã‚‰ãƒ‘ãƒ¼ãƒ„ã‚’æŠœãå–ã‚‹ã¨ã‹ã€ãã‚Œã‚‰ã‚’ï¼‘ï¼ç§’ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ã§å‡¦ç†ã—ã¦ã„ã‹ãªã„ã¨ã„ã‘ãªã„ä¸Šã«ã€ç„¡é‡åŠ›ã§ã®æ“ä½œæ€§ãŒæ‚ªã„ç‚ºã€ç›¸å½“é›£æ˜“åº¦ãŒé«˜ã„ã§ã™ã€‚

ã¾ã ã¾ã ï¼¥ï¼¡ã‚‚å§‹ã¾ã£ãŸæ‰€ã§ã™ã®ã§ã€ä»•æ–¹ãªã„ã‹ã‚‚ã—ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ãŒã€æ„Ÿé›»æ­»ã¯ç„¡ã„æ–¹ãŒã„ã„ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã—ã€ä¸»é›»æºãŒæ­»ã‚“ã ã‚‰ã¯ã„çµ‚ã‚ã‚Šã‚‚ã©ã†ã‹ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã—ã€ã“ã‚Œã‹ã‚‰ã®ã‚¢ãƒƒãƒ—ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ã‚‚ã£ã¨ãƒ—ãƒ¬ã‚¤ãƒ¤ãƒ¼å¯„ã‚Šã«ã™ã‚‹ã‹ã©ã†ã‹ã ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

2Manatee2Furious

31 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
3
RecommandÃ©
206.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 23 novembre 2020
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

I came across this game whilst browsing for titles under Â£12 & Im sooooo glad I did cus I might not of ever discovered it under its own name & what it represents: "Tin Can."

The game puts you in an escape pod being launched from a large exploding Spacecraft.(cutscene) It is then upto you to survive has long has you can by managing the different systems via there components aboard the "Pod" from steller "events" occuring in space - which are (ATM) Ice Nebulas, Electrical Nebulas, Asteriod Collisions & Star Proximities. Each of which event requires different ways of handling your Pods systems & there components to survive them. In saying that there is a learning curve.

Three modes of play are available: Sandbox, Normal, Hardcore. Scenarios are to follow so is a tutorial which is due anytime.

Sandbox Mode
Recently Sandbox has been updated with the features below. Press ESC to access them. This is the ideal way to begin learning the different systems & components. It is perfect for knowing what things do, where they go & how things work together. A Tech Manual describes everything. Have a good old mess about & experiment at your leisure!!!

Summoning Events. Ice, Cold, etc.
Item Damage. Toggle Components damage on/off
Perfect Atmosphere. Sets Atmosphere to perfect regardless of components condition.
Fixed Temperature Same as Atmosphere.
Unlimited repairs The Repair Station has unlimited parts to repair components.

More is to follow.

Normal play
Gives the opportunity to experience what the games about at a slower pace by being faced with different events, Cold, Electric Nebulas, Asteroid collisions & Approaching stars (other events to follow) that require device interaction, repairs & self learning of how best to survive those events. Use the Tech manual has your guide. However a tutorial is becoming available any time soon. Also a good community of players is being established ready to lend a hand to anyone in need.

Hardcore play
I believe was at the heart of the game which creates a PVP leaderboard competition style game by determining who can survive the longest possible time.

I pointed a concern out to the Devs about the Sandbox mode. It simply did not feel like a 'Sandbox' mode considering has to what we know & expect Sandbox games to be about.

On that note the Devs began working on Sandbox features almost straight away!!! I was soooo gobsmacked to see things were added within a few hours!!! Now for that to of occurred that gives these Devs a very high credit in my book cus I've never known any Devs in any game add things that quickly before.

Wrapping up.
Any game is only has good has the Devs that write & support it & with this game in the hands of these quality Devs I believe Tin Can is going to be exceptional. The game is old timer friendly too!!!
 
Capt.Cliffâ„¢

1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante

RecommandÃ©
12.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 30 octobre 2020
Produit reÃ§u gratuitement

Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

So I first discovered this game through a youtube video and thought the concept seemed fun. So I joined the discord and ended up receiving a beta key for testing. The first time I booted it up I thought I would play like about an hour or so (half expecting each run to be the same).......BOY WAS I WRONG........3 hours later I was still pulled in to the chaos of keeping my "tin can" up and running. There are not any huge game breaking bugs and is great......each attempt is different.
The details are what makes this game unique and fun. Opening a drawer that has multiple components feels overwhelming at first but in a fun way.......in a "yep I'm dead" kind of way.
As time goes on you learn where things are and how to manage situations but then chaos strikes in the form of an asteroid, or an ice nebula, or an electrical nebula, ect and you find yourself having "brain farts" and laughing at your mistakes as you die over and over again.......only to boot up another round to try to beat your previous score.
Lastly, the community and the dev are great. Everyone has been helpful and share lots of laughs and strategies as we share how we messed up certain situations.
I would recommend this game and believe this game has a very bright future! If anyone has any questions please feel free to ask.
 
ROUGHiT

Non recommandÃ©
8.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 25 juillet 2022
This is more of a timed, memory game than a technical troubleshooter, which is disappointing. Most modes are entirely scripted affairs; so, not much replay value. I bought into the great concept but the novelty wore off quickly. It's probably worth about half the asking price.

Mr.Ryan
0
40 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
2
Non recommandÃ©
1.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 18 fÃ©vrier 2021
Produit remboursÃ©

Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

You are in an escape pod. Random events happen like flying through asteroids. Which then triggers a random failure that you have to diagnose and fix. You can randomly run out of spare parts and may need to hot swap components around. At some point the situation reaches critical and you die. End game.

It is good but there just not enough depth to the game right now. It starts to become very repetitive. The pod has a technical manual which gives clues on to fix things. The trouble is that is really easy to complete memorise the whole manual in about ten minutes. Then you start to see optimum strategies for survival in each event the pod encounters. So it just becomes a game of using clunky controls to move components until a random sequence of events overwhelms the pile of space parts you have left. It feels very shallow once you start to master it. It is a puzzle game and once the puzzle gets solved replay value starts to drop. It is very early access and is getting more content. However I don't think it will gain replay value once you know how to beat most of the game.

It is good concept and the graphics are starting to look like a master piece even at this stage of development. The quality of the development work going into this really shows through. The only negative thing right now is the controls feel awkward. This is starting to look like a VR edition prototype in the works where an mouse keys where not the first choice for movement.

To make the game more interesting. There is an option to play with a friend. Who gets to read out the instructions from a PDF version of the manual. This does feel a bit like the game keep talking and nobody explodes. However again the limited number of choices the game presents limits it.

A very strong early access start but the game play just does not appeal to me. I would not recommend it but it is something keeping your eyes on. This may still become a classic later down the road. So please put this one your wish list and check it out later. It has potential.
 
Lonewolf
5
18 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
Non recommandÃ©
4.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 5 avril 2023
Tin Can is a fun game, but it unfortunately doesn't have a whole lot of replayability. My expectation for this game was that you would stuck in a shoddy escape pod with failing equipment that gradually degrades, and so the longer the game goes the more sacrifices you have to make in order to survive, until you reach a point where you just don't have enough to work with left and it's game over.

In actuality, the "tin can" works perfectly fine, until some random outside event occurs causing a failure which rapidly cascades into multiple system failures and you die feeling entirely helpless. As you play longer you realise each event has a gimmick you can get around, allowing you to survive each scenario pretty much unscathed. My playtime consisted mostly of watching youtube videos on my other monitor while waiting for some sound cue that an event was occurring, preparing for it quickly, then just waiting it out, switching back systems to normal and then watching more youtube until the next event.

It's an amazing concept for a game, and I had fun discovering the mechanics and optimizing my processes, but once I figured out you could avoid most of the problems from events by turning everything off and just powering critical systems with batteries until the event was over it kind of lost any sense of difficulty.
I think the pod having mechanical failures all on its own would've been more fun. Maybe you have a battery that is a dud and starts discharging too quickly, maybe the oxygen pump starts running too fast, so you can either fix it, replace it, or manage the system by switching it on and off periodically to maintain balance. Maybe the temperature regulator get stuck cooling and so you need to run the reactor hot to maintain temperature. I think that there should be more opportunities for systems to interact with eachother in meaningful ways like that, allowing you to creatively compensate for problems in ways other than just canibalizing a part from a less important system.
 
ChickenPeanut

RecommandÃ©
3.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 20 dÃ©cembre 2021
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

Gameplay 10/10 -not for everyone, however if you like games that keep you on your toes and problem solving, this game is perfect!

Support 15/10 -id give it a 10 if they were on an issue quickly, id give it a 5 for having a post explaining an issue, This 15 is because when i had an issue, I popped in the discord and moments later a dev popped in and asked if there was an issue. I stated what was happening and they said they are actively working on it and explained what happened.

Survivability (of the game, you will still die :P ) 10/10 - When I heard of this game, my first thought was "this would be amazing in vr!" Now that i see they are adding vr as well as the "collection" mechanic at the start, I can see many years of fun (and oxygen deprivation) from this game!

If this game catches your eyes at all, I would check out their discord, see what they have down the line!
 
Viscosity
320 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
23 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
2
RecommandÃ©
33.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 12 mai 2022
Let me start with one phrase. This phrase sets the tone for the whole game and the entire experience you are about to embark on. "Sinking with the ship."

This isn't just about the you. This isn't just about the dinky pod you barely got in. This is about survival, to the very, last, possible second. You have the means to keep this pod going for as long as you possibly can, but it is up to you to prioritize the needs of the systems over the others. Without you, this ship will fall apart, and without the ship your demise is all but guaranteed in this game of mutual survival. You're sinking with the ship. But as it does, the ship sinks with you.

On top of all of this, an official discord is available where the developers are active and friendly. They've already addressed many of the issues that have cropped up during development.

- Le dev prÃ©voit des MAJ rÃ©guliÃ¨res et implique les joueurs sur son channel discord, je vais suivre Ã§a de prÃ¨s et tester rÃ©guliÃ¨rement.
- En l'Ã©tat c'est trÃ¨s propre, les mÃ©caniques fonctionnent bien. Je n'ai pas vu de bug

Ğ¡ÑƒÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ´ĞµÑ€Ğ¶Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒÑÑ ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ (Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾-Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€ Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ¸ Zomboid, Ğ³Ğ´Ğµ Ğ² Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°Ğ»Ğµ Ñƒ Ğ²Ğ°Ñ 100% ÑĞ¼ĞµÑ€Ñ‚ÑŒ).
Ğ•ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½ÑƒĞ°Ğ» (https://cdn.cloudflare.steamstatic.com/steam/apps/1315980/manuals/PDF-ENG.pdf?t=1604034641), ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ½Ğ° Ğ½Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ÑÑ‰Ğ¸Ñ… ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ğ±Ğ»ÑÑ…. Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ» Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ÑÑ‚ÑŒ ÑĞ¾Ğ·Ğ½Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğµ, Ğ¿Ğ¾ĞºĞ° ÑĞ¾Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ğ» ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ÑÑ‚ÑŒ, Ñ‚Ğ°Ğº Ğ¸ ÑƒĞ¼ĞµÑ€ Ñ Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¼ Ğ² Ñ€ÑƒĞºĞ°Ñ… (Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¿Ğ° Ğ²ÑÑ‘ Ğ¼ĞµĞ´Ğ»ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°ĞµÑˆÑŒ Ğ´ĞµĞ»Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ¿Ğ¾ĞºÑĞ¸Ğ¸).
 
Talon
242 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
23 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
3
Non recommandÃ©
2.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 7 aout 2022
Sometimes I want to be generous and recommend, but can't. The question isn't do I see merits, or can I see why people would enjoy this, but would *I* recommend it to another person based on my experience with it. Sadly not. The prevailing issue is that there's just not much here. In the early levels you lose if you didn't get the right part before boarding the pod, and in the later modes its ... well, I figured it out pretty quick. All you are doing is deciding what you can lose. That's it. All this talk about it being some kind of intricate simulation is grossly misleading. I'm going straight for the throat with this one: I literally opened the door to my pod and held it in the open position for roughly a couple minutes before I died of asphyxiation. I had enough time to realize it wasn't working, turn off all the other systems and then go back to holding the door open. Yeah, what a rich and detailed biological and mechanical simulation we're participating in.

The door opens, the mechanics are all there, so the developer put it in. But all it it does is show off how the game doesn't do much. We literally opened a door into space and the game can't even kill me quickly, let alone in an interesting way. So, if you were hoping for some emergent gameplay where you figure out how to repair the CO2 scrubber with a paperclip and some duct tape, this ain't it. Either you have the parts you need, or you lose. Once you figure out the failures, it's boring. You realize all you are doing is waiting for a failure, doing what it requires or, if you can't, waiting several minutes to suffocate. Speaking of having the right part, the game utilizes some RNG to spice things up. I don't want to complain about this since it's kind of the only thing elevating this above basic memorization, but ultimately does little: you either have a part or you don't. Once you have all the stations unlocked you have more interesting options for repairs, but you'll have seen everything the game has to offer long before that.

I like this game in concept more than I like it in execution. If I got it for free I'd probably ignore these flaws more, but as a product I paid for I think I'm well justified being disappointed in it. Of course, I didn't bother to talk about all the bugs here since I was able to largely ignore them. I got stuck in the ceiling, stuff passes through walls, clicking on anything with any level of precision is an absolute nightmare: it feels a bit like Surgeon Simulator. Yeah, the game is boring and pretty buggy. Hell of a combo, but I'm not sure if that's intentional. If it lent into it's â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, boring characteristics it could at least be an anti-game. As it is now, it's neither fun to play or interestingly bad. So no, I don't recommend it unless you just want to patron the arts.
 
Hyomoto
0
20 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
Non recommandÃ©
1.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 15 mai 2022
I think that there is probably something to be gained from this game and I think it has potential but the loop of: search for parts you don't know if you will need, read error messages that don't tell you anything helpful, and then die because I didn't grab the part I needed is aggravating. If I spawned with at least 1 of each part, or started with the ability to fix parts this would be infinitely better. At this point it feels like a game of confusion, luck, and memorization; which is a cocktail to make any game unfun.
 
Soulless megacorp
294 produits enregistrÃ©s

18 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile

RecommandÃ©
5.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 7 aout 2023
This game is currently in the Humble Choice for August 2023, this is part of my coverage of the bundle. If you are interested in the game and it's before September 5th, 2022, consider picking up the game as part of the current monthly bundle.

Life Pod Simulator.

Tin Can starts with the player on a ship thatâ€™s about to blow up in 60 seconds. They can grab all the supplies they can bring to the life pod, one at a time, but after that point, they will escape off the ship and wait for a rescue shuttle to pick them up in that pod. The main mode has 6 survival missions ranging from 6 minutes to 30 minutes, each with what seems like a set script of what is going to go wrong. Thereâ€™s also a challenge mode with different challenges.

That being said, this is a game mostly about figuring out what is wrong, and how to solve it. This speaks heavily to the part of my brain that loves Zachtronics games and programming, but that also means most players might not enjoy it at that level. I had a lot of trouble figuring out the first issue with the pod, but now that I understand that one, the second mission was relatively easy, and Iâ€™m looking forward to even more.

Pick this up if you like puzzle-solving and dealing with problems, especially in a high-pressure situation. Limiting the problem area, and focusing on diagnosing the computer systems feels pretty fresh, but also thereâ€™s probably a limited number of unique missions here, so once youâ€™ve run each survival and completed it, Iâ€™m not sure how much there is to do, even the challenges will be a bit limited, as thereâ€™s only a certain number of events that can happen.

If you enjoyed this review or want to know what I think of other games in the bundle, check out the full review on or subscribe to my Youtube channel:
VidÃ©o YouTubeâ„¢: Humble Choice August 2023 Review: A Stellar Month 
Vues : 3,764
Another month, another choice, and this month is exceptional. Let's talk about why. Opening - 00:00 Disco Elysium - The Final Cut - 00:30 Chivalry 2 - 02:19 Road 96 - 03:40 Trek to Yomi - 04:50...

 
King Link
2,935 produits enregistrÃ©s
1
11 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
0
Non recommandÃ©
3.4 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 11 aout 2023
I wanted to like this game but it's far too buggy to be fun.

First off the game is very much designed for VR and it has a lot of weird design choices that just get in the way when using mouse and keyboard. For movement and positioning you must constantly hold down a mouse button to not lose your grip on nearby handles, it's very VR and not an ergonomic experience on pc. The items you pick up are physically being held in gamespace and part of the physics simulation, so you'll get all sorts of weird behaviour as the objects your holding (one for each hand) clip into things and spazz out in all manner of ways. Trying to install or remove the right component is incredibly frustrating, and the same input is used for installation as interaction; More often than not the object your holding will be dropped despite the component placement aid showing proper placement. Compartments may even open and close as your held object collides with them, as you are trying to install said object.

Components will constantly suffer from common physics engine bugs, fly off at sonic speeds, go missing, or end up in the walls or under the floor grate. If the game were slower paced and more thoughtful maybe I could deal with this, but the whole thing is just a frantic and frustrating series of unlikely failures as you struggle with the interface and buggy nonsense more so than the failing systems themselves.

Add to this mess a bunch of extra frustrating gameplay elements and you really drive the nail in the space coffin. For example certain components can overload and all the lights will go out, including emergency lighting. You have a flashlight for this, and it's not great, but it only has a handful of seconds of battery life. WTH, Why!? Stumbling around in the dark with a faulty flashlight in zero-g and no idea where the handles are is not fun. It's the opposite of fun. It's not even a 'challenge' thing, it's just absurd. If something fails you have at most a minute or two to diagnose it before you die. CO2 Scubber fails, fix it immediately or die. Temperature? same. Oxygen, pressure, etc. It's less a thoughtful survival game and more a mad dash to fit blocks into boxes as quickly as possible before you suffocate.
 
sascha snowstorm
0
20 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
2
RecommandÃ©
2.4 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 17 mai 2022
Produit reÃ§u gratuitement

è¿™ç¯‡è¯„æµ‹ä¸ºåŒè¯­
This review is bilingual

å¤ªé•¿ä¸çœ‹ï¼šå¾ˆå¥½çš„ç‚¹å­ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æ‰§è¡Œçš„ä¸å¥½ï¼Œè€Œä¸”éœ€è¦æ›´ç»†å¿ƒçš„æ‰“ç£¨ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯ä»½ä¸­è¯„
TL;DR: Great idea poorly executed, and needs serious polishing. This is a neutral review.

ä¼˜ç‚¹

- æ•™ç¨‹éå¸¸ä¼˜ç§€ï¼Œç®€çŸ­è€Œè€äººå¯»å‘³ï¼ŒåŸºæœ¬è®²åˆ°äº†æ¸¸æˆçš„é‡ç‚¹ï¼Œä½†åˆä¸æ˜¯å®Œå…¨çš„æ‰‹æŠŠæ‰‹æ•™ä½ ã€‚åœ¨æ•™ç¨‹æœ€åçš„ä¸€å…³ç”šè‡³æ‰¿ä¸Šå¯ä¸‹äº†è§£é‡Šäº†æ­£å¼æ¸¸æˆä¸€å¼€å§‹ä½ è¦å¹²å˜›ï¼Œéå¸¸è‡ªç„¶ã€‚

- ä½ æœ‰ä¸¤åªæ‰‹ã€‚

- ä¸Šæ‰‹å®¹æ˜“ç²¾é€šå›°éš¾ã€‚ä½ èƒ½è½»æ˜“åœ°è¿‡ç¬¬ä¸€ç¬¬äºŒå…³ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä»ç¬¬ä¸‰å…³å¼€å§‹å°±è¦å¼€å§‹ç ”ç©¶ç­–ç•¥äº†ã€‚æœ‰äº›ä¸œè¥¿åäº†å°±åäº†ï¼Œæœ‰äº›ä¸œè¥¿æ²¡åä¹Ÿè¦èˆå¼ƒï¼Œä¿æ›´é‡è¦çš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œåœ¨ç´§æ€¥å…³å¤´çš„å–èˆä¸å†³ç­–æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆçš„ç²¾é«“ã€‚

- ä½œä¸ºèˆªçº¿é£è¡Œå‘˜ï¼Œæˆ‘æ„Ÿå—åˆ°äº†é£æ¨¡æ‹Ÿæœºç§‘ç›®æ—¶å€™çš„å‹åŠ›ã€‚

Pros

- Great tutorial. Itâ€™s short but concise, cut right to the core gameplay but not completely babysitting. In the final stage of the tutorial, it even foreshadows the plot, making the main game far more natural.

- You have two hands

- Easy to learn, hard to master. You can just get past the first two stages without any problems. Starting from stage three, however, you need to study your strategy. Something that breaks, is gone for good; Something that is working, needs to be torn apart. You sacrifice your not-so-important systems for core, life-supporting systems. The decision-making in emergency situation is the essence of the game.

- As an airline pilot, I feel the pressure sitting in a full flight simulator.

ç¼ºç‚¹

- æœ¬åœ°åŒ–ï¼šè™½ç„¶æ•´ä¸ªé¡¹ç›®ä¸€çœ‹å°±æ˜¯ä¸­å›½äººç¿»è¯‘çš„ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æœ‰è¿‡åº¦ç¿»è¯‘çš„å«Œç–‘ï¼Œæªè¾è¿‡äºæ¿€è¿›ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚â€you can go back to your cleaningâ€ï¼Œåœ¨ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­ä»…æœ‰â€œä½ å¯ä»¥å›å»ç»§ç»­å¹²æ´»/æ‰“æ‰«äº†â€çš„æ„æ€ï¼Œè¢«ç¿»è¯‘æˆäº†â€œä½ è¿˜æ˜¯å“ªå‡‰å¿«å“ªå‘†ç€å»â€ï¼Œä¸å¦¥ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œæ–‡æœ¬ä¸­ä¹Ÿæœ‰é”™å­—ï¼Œå°šéœ€æ‰“ç£¨ã€‚è€Œä¸”è¿›å…¥æ¸¸æˆï¼Œé»˜è®¤çš„è¯­è¨€è®¾å®šå¥‡å¥‡æ€ªæ€ªï¼Œåƒæ˜¯å®Œå…¨æ²¡æœ‰æœ¬åœ°åŒ–ï¼Œç”šè‡³ä¸æ˜¯é»˜è®¤è‹±è¯­ï¼ˆèœå•ä¸­æœ‰@ï¼‰ï¼Œè°ƒæˆä¸­æ–‡éœ€è¦å…ˆè°ƒåˆ«çš„è¯­è¨€å†è°ƒå›ä¸­æ–‡ã€‚

- ç¢°æ’ç®±ï¼šæœ‰æ—¶å€™ä¼šå‘å‡ºè¿ç»­ä¸æ–­çš„ç¢°æ’å£°ï¼Œæ¨¡å‹ä¼šæŠ–åŠ¨ï¼Œç”šè‡³æ˜¯ç©å®¶ç‰©å“ç©¿æ¨¡

- ç³Ÿç³•çš„UIï¼šèœå•é‡Œä¿®æ”¹éƒ¨åˆ†é€‰é¡¹å#FF0000çš„é¢œè‰²æ˜¯è®¤çœŸçš„å—ï¼Ÿæ•™ç¨‹æ–‡æœ¬æ¡†çš„#0000FFåˆæ˜¯è®¤çœŸçš„å—ï¼Ÿ
èœå•é‡Œå››ä¸ªå¤§æ¡†æ²¡ä¸œè¥¿æ˜¯å¯¹é½äº†çš„ï¼Œå­—ä½“ä¹Ÿä¸ä¸€è‡´ï¼Œé€‰æ‹©è¯­è¨€çš„æ¡†å’Œæ²™ç›’æ¨¡å¼ä¸­æ¡†çš„å­—ä½“æ˜¯é»˜è®¤çš„ã€‚

â€¦â€¦

è¿™ç§å°çš„ç‘•ç–µæ¯”æ¯”çš†æ˜¯ï¼Œè®©äººæ„Ÿè§‰è¿™ä¸è¯¥æ˜¯ä¸ªReleaseï¼Œæœ€å¤šç®—ä¸ªEA

- ç³Ÿç³•çš„UXï¼šæš‚åœèœå•ä¸­æŠŠé€€å‡ºåˆ°æ¡Œé¢æ”¾æœ€ä¸‹é¢ï¼Œè€Œä¸”æ²¡æœ‰ç¡®è®¤ï¼›è®¾ç½®å’Œé€€å‡ºåˆ°èœå•çš„ä½ç½®ä¹Ÿè¯¥å¯¹è°ƒ

â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥

- Localisation: (not applicable here)

- Collision: Sometimes colliding sound plays too often, while the model shakes violently. Things like drawer donâ€™t have collision boxes

- Poor UI: #FF0000 when you change settings? Seriously? #0000FF in the tutorial textbox? Seriously?
Textboxes in settings donâ€™t vertically align across different view groups.
Inconsistent font family: The font in language selection box and sandbox mode configuration selection box is default
Inconsistent font size: Text in sandbox configuration is too small. Hard to read.
Text in back button is not vertically centeredâ€¦
â€¦

Small things like this here and there really gets on oneâ€™s nerve. Seriously, fix your obvious flaws before you call yourself a â€œreleaseâ€. Itâ€™s EA quality at most!

- Poor UX: In pause menu, EXIT TO DESKTOP is placed at the bottom WITH NO CONFIRMATION. I accidentally quit the game twice.
Settings and Back to menu should be swapped as well.

é‡å¤§å·¥ä¸šè®¾è®¡ç‘•ç–µ

è¿™ä¸ªé€ƒç”Ÿèˆ±çš„å·¥ä¸šè®¾è®¡æ˜¯å®Œå…¨çš„ä¸åŠæ ¼äº§å“

- æ‰‹å†Œï¼šæ•´ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆä¸­åº”è¯¥æœ€é‡è¦çš„æ‰‹å†Œï¼Œå´å®Œå…¨æ˜¯é¸¡è‚‹ï¼Œä½ èƒ½ç”¨åˆ°çš„æœ‰ä¸”ä»…æœ‰ç›®å½•ä¸­é”™è¯¯ä»£ç çš„ä¸€é¡µï¼Œå…¶ä»–åªç”¨è¯»ä¸€éï¼Œå®Œå…¨æ²¡ç”¨ã€‚ç¼ºå°‘è¯¦ç»†çš„ç³»ç»Ÿæè¿°ä»¥åŠå¦‚ä½•ç»´ä¿®ã€‚
æ—¢ç„¶æ˜¯ç”µå­æ‰‹å†Œï¼Œé‚£å°±åº”è¯¥æœ‰è¶…é“¾æ¥æˆ–è€…å¯äº¤äº’ç›®å½•çš„åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå®é™…ä¸Šåœ¨è¿è¡Œçš„å‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰ç”µå­æ‰‹å†Œéƒ½æœ‰è¿™ä¸ªåŠŸèƒ½äº†ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æ¸¸æˆæ²¡æœ‰ã€‚æ²¡æœ‰ï¼Œä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦æŠŠç›®å½•æ ‡é¢˜åšæˆè“è‰²çš„å‘¢ï¼Ÿ
æœ€åŸºæœ¬çš„æ£€æŸ¥å•ä¸€ä¸ªéƒ½æ²¡æœ‰ï¼šæ£€æŸ¥å•&æ ‡å‡†æ“ä½œç¨‹åºï¼ˆSOPï¼‰æ˜¯èˆªç©ºèˆªå¤©ç­‰æ´»åŠ¨çš„åŸºç¡€ï¼Œè€Œåœ¨æ‰‹å†Œé‡Œä¸€ç‚¹éƒ½æ²¡æœ‰æåˆ°ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ è§‰å¾—æ—¶é—´ç´§è¿«ï¼Œè¯»å’Œåšæ£€æŸ¥å•ä¸€èˆ¬éƒ½æ¥ä¸åŠï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸ªç†Ÿèƒ½ç”Ÿå·§çš„æ¸¸æˆï¼Œæœ€èµ·ç åšä¸€äº›è®°å¿†é¡¹ç›®æ£€æŸ¥å•ã€‚

- äº‹å®æ€§é”™è¯¯ï¼šæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæŸœå­å«â€œæ¶²å‹è®¾å¤‡â€ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯é‡Œé¢æ˜¯æ°”æ³µå’Œæ»¤èŠ¯ï¼Œè¿™å’Œæ¶²å‹æœ‰å…³ç³»å—ï¼Ÿ

- è¿åå·¥ä¸šè®¾è®¡ï¼šç©ºå®¢å’Œç°ä»£æ³¢éŸ³é‡‡ç”¨â€œæš—èˆ±ç†å¿µâ€ï¼šå³ç³»ç»Ÿæ­£å¸¸è¿è¡Œçš„æ—¶å€™æ²¡æœ‰ç¯äº®ã€‚è¿™æ¸¸æˆçš„å¼€å…³ç®€ç›´åäººç±»ï¼šå¼€çš„æ—¶å€™äº®ç»¿ç¯ï¼Œå…³çš„æ—¶å€™ä¸äº®ç¯ï¼Ÿï¼Ÿé£èˆ¹ç³»ç»Ÿåº”è¯¥å¸®åŠ©å®‡èˆªå‘˜è€Œä¸æ˜¯å’Œå®‡èˆªå‘˜ä½œå¯¹ã€‚

- æ³¨æ„åŠ›å¸å¼•è£…ç½®ï¼š
é¦–å…ˆï¼ŒæŒ‰é’®è¢«ç§°ä½œâ€œMASTERâ€ WARN/CAUTæ˜¯æœ‰é“ç†çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå…¨é©¾é©¶èˆ±åªéœ€è¦ä¸€ä¸ªã€‚å•ç‹¬ç³»ç»Ÿçš„æŒ‡ç¤ºç¯åº”è¯¥ç”¨å•ç‹¬çš„FAULTç¯æˆ–åˆ«çš„è®¾è®¡ï¼Œä¸ç„¶MASTERåœ¨å“ªé‡Œï¼Ÿ
å…¶æ¬¡ï¼ŒPUSH TO RESETçš„æ ¹æœ¬ç†å¿µå°±æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†æ­¢å“æ­¢é—ªï¼Œä»è€Œè®©å·²ç»çŸ¥æ‚‰æ•…éšœçš„å®‡èˆªå‘˜èƒ½å¤Ÿä¸“æ³¨äºæ‰‹ä¸Šçš„å·¥ä½œï¼Œæ’æ•…ä¿®å¤ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆçš„æŒ‰é’®ï¼ŒæŒ‰äº†ç­‰äºæ²¡æŒ‰ï¼Œæ­¢å“ä¸¤ç§’ï¼Œåˆå¼€å§‹å«å¼€å§‹é—ªï¼ŒåŸºæœ¬ä¸§å¤±äº†ä»–çš„æ„ä¹‰ï¼Œåªæ˜¯ä¸ºäº†å‹åŠ›è€Œå‹åŠ›ã€‚

Major industrial design flaws

This escape pod is a completely defective product

- Manual: Supposed to be the base of this game, turns out to be a piece of complete garbage. All you will use is ONE page in ToC showing those error codes. Other pages, you read once, and throw away. Thereâ€™s no useful information there. Itâ€™s not going to tell you how to diagnose or fix a down generator. Too little information in individual systems.
You do realise that this is a pdf manual right? So make hyperlinks and/or interactive ToC then. Most EFBs in operation feature this to help the pilots quickly locate contents. If you donâ€™t have this feature, why bother making the ToC text blue, like a hyperlink?
Moreover, CHECKLIST & SOP IS A MUST in aviation / astronautical activities. But is not mentioned anywhere in the manual. If you feel like this game gives you no time to do a thorough READ & DO checklist, at least include some memory items.

- Factual error: There is a cabinet called â€œhydraulic equipmentsâ€, which contains AIR pumps and AIR filters. How is this remotely related to â€œhydraulicsâ€?

- Designs that violate guidelines: Airbus and modern Boeing features â€œdark cockpit philosophyâ€, meaning if everything is alright, no lights should come up. The switches in this game, oh manâ€¦ The light illuminates green when itâ€™s on, but illuminates NOTHING when itâ€™s off. Are you guys deliberately making this game harder by doing crappy designs? Pod systems are supposed to HELP pilots instead of FIGHT pilots.

- Attention getters:
First off, â€œMASTERâ€ WARN/CAUT is called like this for a reason. Because you only need one in the entire cockpit, hence â€œMASTERâ€. Make another â€œFAULTâ€ light or whatever for individual systems.

Then, the sole purpose of â€œPUSH TO RESETâ€ is to stop visual and aural warning when the pilot is informed of the error. And leave them focus on their own work. The button in this game simply does not work. It stops the warning for literally two seconds and the warning goes off again. So whatâ€™s the purpose of this? Itâ€™s pressure-inducing for the sake of being pressure-inducing.

æ€»ç»“

(7/10) æ¦‚å¿µå¾ˆæœ‰è¶£ï¼Œæœ‰åšçš„å¾ˆå¥½ç©å¾ˆä¸“ä¸šçš„æ½œè´¨ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ç°åœ¨æ— è®ºæ˜¯ä¸“ä¸šæ€§ï¼ˆæ¨¡æ‹Ÿçš„éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼‰å’Œæ¸¸æˆæ€§ï¼ˆå¥½ç©çš„éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼‰éƒ½æ¬ ç¼ºçš„æ¯”è¾ƒå¤šï¼Œéœ€è¦æ‰“ç£¨çš„åœ°æ–¹å¾ˆæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šã€‚æˆ‘ä¸è®¤ä¸ºè¿™æ˜¯ä¸ªåˆæ ¼çš„å‘è¡Œç‰ˆæ¸¸æˆï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä¸ªæœ‰æ½œåŠ›çš„EAæ¸¸æˆ

Verdict

(7/10) The game sure has interesting concepts and has the potential of being really fun and hardcore. For the time being though, it lacks both professionality (simulation part) and fun (gaming part), hence needs LOTS of polishing. Again, I do not consider this done and release. But it sure is a good EA game with high potential.

Non recommandÃ©
0.6 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 1 juin 2022
Produit remboursÃ©

Played the demo. Thought I was getting a thoughtful problem solving simulation game set in space. The demo plays as a slow paced problem solving game. Thought it would expand to bigger and more complex systems/scenarios.

What I got was a frantic arcade game where you are just trying to survive for as long as possible, but the first couple "missions" ended up with me surviving despite not actually doing anything. This feels more like an early access title than a full release. The kicker is that the core mechanics are actually pretty good with a lot of potential, but it doesn't seem like the developers are interested in developing beyond those core mechanics...

I obviously asked for a refund in less than an hour of purchasing the game.

TL;DR The demo is better than and not representative of the full game. The full game is more or less an early access game that for some reason was released as a full game. Great potential, but disappointing execution.

Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

Cocorico ! Bravo Ã  cette petite Ã©quipe franÃ§aise indÃ©pendante dont le jeu sors des sentiers battus :

"Tin Can" littÃ©ralement boite de conserve, ou comment s'Ã©chapper et survivre dans une capsule de sauvetage hors de contrÃ´le qui Ã¨re dans l'espace infini ; on subira des Ã©vÃ©nements alÃ©atoires (champs d'astÃ©roÃ¯de, orages Ã©lectriques....) qui entraÃ®neront des dommages : il faudra alors maintenir les systÃ¨mes vitaux en Ã©tant de fonctionnement en sacrifiant peut Ãªtre ceux qui le sont moins et qui sait peut Ãªtre, Ãªtre enfin secouru.

Pour la sortie du jeu, l'Ã©quipe est trÃ¨s rÃ©active et Ã  l'Ã©coute pour la correction des bugs : c'est encore une version en accÃ¨s anticipÃ©. Il y a possibilitÃ© de jouer en coop Ã  la maniÃ¨re d'un "Keep Talking and nobody explodes", l'un intervient, l'autre lis le manuel.

Ludoboy

14 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile

RecommandÃ©
10.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 31 dÃ©cembre 2020
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

For a game that's mostly the effort of one developer, this is a phenomenal early access release. It looks great, the gameplay loop is smooth, and while you will die a lot, there's a feeling of learning a little extra each time. I haven't encountered any bugs thus far.

While the game is in early access, it's clear there are some very good things planned on the horizon. More pod variety, more events, more scenarios, and the ability to get rescued.

There's also a play-with-friends options, which only gives you error diagnostics, so you'll need a friend with the manual (which anyone can download) to help out. Think Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes crossed with Nauticrawl.

This will absolutely be a great game for everyone who enjoys dying alone in space.

Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

Love the little can that constantly tries to kill me. It's a great game to deal with a mess under stress. And it's come a long way since it's first open access release.
It's not very sandboxy, the solutions you'll have to develop are usually very specific to the problem space throws at you. Which means you die, like a lot, but it's fun!

æç¤ºï¼Œè¿™ä¸æ˜¯æ•æ·çš„æ“ä½œä¿®å¤ä¸œè¥¿çš„æ¸¸æˆï¼Œæ˜¯èµ„æºç®¡ç†/ç­–ç•¥/è®°å¿†åŠ›æ¸¸æˆã€‚ä¸ºäº†åº”å¯¹æŸåå¿…é¡»æ‹†é™¤ç°æœ‰çš„ç³»ç»Ÿæ¥ç»´ä¿®ï¼Œä¸ºäº†ç”Ÿå­˜ä½ å¿…é¡»é€‰æ‹©å¤±å»äº›ä»€ä¹ˆï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬æ˜¾ç¤ºé”™è¯¯çš„æ˜¾ç¤ºå±ã€å¼€å…³æŒ‰é’®ã€è­¦å‘Šç¯ã€èœ‚é¸£å™¨ã€‚å°†å¯é€šç”¨é›¶ä»¶çš„ç³»ç»Ÿæ‹†æ‰ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œéœ€è¦å†ä»å…¶ä»–ç³»ç»Ÿä¸­æ‹¿è¿‡æ¥è£…ä¸Šã€‚ä½ å¾—æ—¶åˆ»æ³¨æ„æœºæ¢°ç©ºæ°”æˆåˆ†è¡¨ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä½ ç•™ä¸‹å”¯ä¸€æç¤ºä½ çš„å£°éŸ³æˆ–ç¯å¯èƒ½ä¼šåã€‚
æ¸¸æˆå†…å®¹æŒºå¥½çš„ä½†æ²¡ä¹°çš„ä¸è¦è¯¯ä¼šæ¸¸æˆç±»å‹äº†ã€‚

Non recommandÃ©
1.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 22 dÃ©cembre 2022
Best to avoid unless you enjoy beta testing software.

The game is clunky and awkward to play. Simple things like selecting objects and placing them just hasn't had enough care to make it anything but frustrating. Placing objects takes many attempts. You'll find objects highlighted for selection in drawers which you can't see.

As an example of what to expect, even in the very first *tutorial* you open a drawer with an oxygen bottle which highlights as you hover over it. There is an onscreen instruction "Press CLICK to take". Except you can't take it - and you don't even need to. Nice..

It didn't get much better I'm afraid for the time I was prepared to invest. To the developers: If you want people to play games like this you need to spend the time to polish them and make it satisfying rather than awkward and frustrating. If you need a lot of practice to perform simple tasks that might just be a problem with the way you've implemented it, yeah? In other games players can just pick things up and put them where they expect right away. And they don't get given tasks they can't perform that they don't need to do anyway.
 
deepskydiver
0
13 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
114.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 7 juin 2021
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

One of the best system simulations in an indie game. It focuses heavily on this aspect, and the production quality is very high probably partially thanks to the narrow focus. But even after you have seen all of the basics of the gameplay loop, you still haven't seen everything.

There is more than meets the eye

Tin Can reveals surprising depth and attention to detail in the systems simulation, as well as how external events in space affect them. There are multiple ways to deal with problems with varying effectiveness and amount of work, time and danger involved in solving them. There are strategies to deal with individual problems, as well as overall strategy with how you approach your entire run. Experimenting with different approaches extend the hours of fun you'll get out of this. Although I have to mention that I have found "the best" solution to each of the encounters that I would be tempted to use every time if the idea of experimentation wasn't more interesting.

It is also exciting

Even if you think that system simulation sounds boring, the devs have thought of even that. When things don't go according to your plan (if you even had a plan), it's easy to panic as lights go out, oxygen runs low or CO2 high, generator shuts down, hull starts creaking from pressure and multiple different system alarm sounds fill the escape pod competing for your attention and reminding you that your demise is approaching fast if you don't deal with them soon. Unless some alarm systems are broken, in which case it is startling to discover that the safety line you expected to be there to warn you actually doesn't exist, and you are way farther in serious trouble than you would have been if the alarm had sounded or the light flashed early on.

The future looks good

Absolutely fantastic work from the developers so far. The future plans they have for this game sound equally great and high quality as the existing part of it (in version 0.0.66c) and if the plans get realized with the same amount of care that has been taken so far, and with equal quality, that will only perfect the already great game even more.

Tin Can might not give you 500 hours worth of content, but every hour it does, will surely be worth it. After 18 hours, I have now survived through all of the current events in the game multiple times, but i have to go back. My escape pod awaits :)
 
ScifiSpirit
598 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
10 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
30.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 14 janvier 2023
ä¸€ç›´å£å°±ä¸€ç›´ä¿®ï¼æ²’äººèƒ½é˜»æ­¢æˆ‘å›å®¶çš„æ±ºå¿ƒï¼
å…¶å¯¦ä¸€é–‹å§‹æ˜¯æ‰“ç®—çµ¦è² è©•çš„ï¼Œä½†æœ€å¾Œå»æ„ˆç©æ„ˆä¸Šç™®ï¼Œç”šè‡³é‚„æ‰“äº†ä¸€ç¯‡æŒ‡å—çµ¦ç¹ä¸­ç©å®¶å€‘ã€‚

Tin Canï¼ˆä¸­è­¯ã€Šé€ƒç”Ÿè‰™æ¨¡æ“¬å™¨ã€‹ï¼‰æ˜¯ä¸€æ¬¾æ¨¡æ“¬åœ¨å¤ªç©ºé€ƒç”Ÿè‰™è£¡ç­‰å¾…æ•‘æ´çš„ç¡¬æ ¸ç”Ÿå­˜éŠæˆ²ï¼Œéç¨‹ä¸­ç©å®¶éœ€è¦ç®¡ç†è‰™å…§å¤šå€‹ç³»çµ±ä»¥ç¶­æŒåˆé©çš„ç”Ÿå­˜ç’°å¢ƒï¼Œè€Œä¸”é‚„ä¸æ™‚æœƒé‡åˆ°å„ç¨®å¤ªç©ºäº‹ä»¶ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æ¥è¿‘é‡åŠ›å¥‡é»æˆ–é«˜ç†±æ†æ˜Ÿç­‰ï¼Œé€™äº›äº‹ä»¶éƒ½æœƒå½±éŸ¿è‰™å…§ç’°å¢ƒå’Œç³»çµ±çš„é‹ä½œï¼Œå¦‚æœè™•ç†ä¸ç•¶ï¼Œå°±æœ‰å¯èƒ½å°è‡´ç³»çµ±çš„é›¶ä»¶æå£ï¼Œç”šè‡³ç›´æ¥è®“ä½ æˆç‚ºå¤ªç©ºåƒåœ¾ã€‚

ğŸ”¸ éŠæˆ²è£¡æœ‰å¤šå€‹æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œé€šé—œæ¢ä»¶ä¹Ÿå„æœ‰ä¸åŒã€‚

    å€‹äººèªç‚ºé€™æ˜¯çœŸæ­£è®“ç©å®¶äº†è§£èˆ‡ç†Ÿæ‚‰éŠæˆ²æ©Ÿåˆ¶çš„æ¨¡å¼ã€‚é–‹å ´æ™‚ç©å®¶æœ‰ 1 åˆ†é˜æ™‚é–“åœ¨å€‰åº«æ”¶é›†éœ€è¦çš„é›¶ä»¶ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œç”Ÿå­˜é”æŒ‡å®šçš„æ™‚é–“é•·åº¦ï¼Œå¾ç¬¬ä¸€é—œç”Ÿå­˜ 6 åˆ†é˜åˆ°æœ€å¾Œä¸€é—œ 30 åˆ†é˜ï¼Œè€Œæ¯ä¸€é—œæœƒç™¼ç”Ÿçš„äº‹ä»¶éƒ½æ˜¯å›ºå®šçš„ï¼Œè®“ç©å®¶å¯ä»¥å¾å¤±æ•—ä¸­æ…¢æ…¢å­¸ç¿’è™•ç†äº‹ä»¶çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å¦‚æœå¤§å®¶è¦ºå¾—æœ‰å›°é›£çš„è©±ï¼Œå¯ä»¥åƒè€ƒç­†è€…è£½ä½œçš„æŒ‡å—ï¼Œå®ƒå¯ä»¥å¤§å¤§æ¸›å°‘ä½ åœ¨éŠæˆ²éç¨‹ä¸­é‡åˆ°çš„æŒ«æ•—æ„Ÿã€‚

    Un guide pour Tin Can
    Par : FL
    é€™éŠæˆ²æä¾›çš„æ•™å­¸çœŸçš„å¾ˆä¸å®Œæ•´ï¼Œåªæ•™äº†ä¸€äº›æœ€åŸºæœ¬çš„æ“ä½œå’Œç”Ÿå­˜è¦æ±‚å°±æ²’äº†ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç•¶ä½ é–‹å§‹ç©æ•‘æ´æ¨¡å¼çš„æ™‚å€™å°±æœƒé‡åˆ°ä¸€å †å¾ä¾†æ²’ä»‹ç´¹éçš„ç³»çµ±å’Œå•é¡Œï¼Œæ–°æ‰‹åªèƒ½ç›²äººæ‘¸è±¡åœ°å»å˜—è©¦ï¼Œä½†å…¶å¯¦æ•´å€‹éç¨‹é‚„è »å‹¸é€€äººçš„ï¼Œå¦‚æœä½ æƒ³è¼•é¬†ä¸€é»åº¦éé€™å€‹é™£ç—›æœŸçš„è©±ï¼Œé‚£ä¸‹é¢å°±çµ¦å¤§å®¶ä¸€äº›å¯¦ç”¨æŠ€å·§å’Œé€šé—œæç¤ºã€‚

  • å…·æŒ‘æˆ°æ€§çš„éŠæˆ²è¨­è¨ˆã€‚ç©å®¶åœ¨éç¨‹ä¸­åŸºæœ¬ä¸Šæ²’æœ‰ç”šéº¼é–’é¤˜çš„æ™‚é–“ï¼Œå› ç‚ºéœ€è¦æ™‚æ™‚åˆ»åˆ»è§€å¯Ÿè‘—æ¯å€‹æ©Ÿå™¨çš„è®€æ•¸ä»¥ç¶­æŒå®ƒå€‘çš„é‹ä½œï¼Œå¦‚æœæ©Ÿå™¨å£äº†å°±è¦åœ¨ç¶­ä¿®æ‰‹å†Šè£¡æŸ¥éŒ¯èª¤ä»£ç¢¼å†é€²è¡Œç¶­ä¿®ï¼Œæ“¬çœŸæ„Ÿå¾ˆé«˜ã€‚å¦å¤–éŠæˆ²ä¹Ÿè€ƒé©—ç©å®¶åœ¨å£“åŠ›æƒ…æ³ä¸‹çš„è§£é›£èƒ½åŠ›ï¼Œå°¤å…¶æ˜¯åœ¨å››ã€äº”å€‹ç³»çµ±è­¦å ±åŒæ™‚åœ¨éŸ¿çš„æ™‚å€™ï¼Œæ›´éœ€è¦ä¸æ…Œä¸å¿™çš„å»é€ä¸€è™•ç†ï¼Œè€Œç•¶ç©å®¶é †åˆ©æŠŠå®ƒå€‘è§£æ±ºå°±æœƒæœ‰ä¸€ç¨®è«åçš„æ»¿è¶³æ„Ÿã€‚

  • ç¼ºä¹è©³ç´°çš„æ•™å­¸å’Œèªªæ˜ã€‚å¯èƒ½æ˜¯å› ç‚ºéŠæˆ²å®šä½çš„åŸå› ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥éŠæˆ²å…§æä¾›çš„æ•™å­¸åªæ•™äº†æœ€åŸºæœ¬çš„çŸ¥è­˜ï¼Œç©å®¶éœ€è¦è‡ªå·±èŠ±å¤šå€‹å°æ™‚å»äº†è§£å„å€‹ç³»çµ±èˆ‡æ©Ÿåˆ¶ï¼Œé›£åº¦æ›²ç·šéå¸¸é«˜ï¼Œé€™å°æ–°æ‰‹ä¾†èªªä¸å‹å–„ï¼Œå¾ˆå®¹æ˜“å› ç‚ºé€²å…¥ä¸äº†ç‹€æ³è€Œè¢«å‹¸é€€ã€‚

  • éŠæˆ²éç¨‹åŸºæœ¬ä¸Šè¦ 360 åº¦å…¨æ–¹ä½æ“ä½œï¼Œä½†è¹²èˆ‡ç«™ç«‹çš„é«˜åº¦å°æŸäº›ä½ç½®ä¾†èªªæœƒæœ‰é»å°·å°¬ï¼ŒåŠ ä¸Šç„æº–çš„åˆ¤å®šè¦æ±‚åš´æ ¼ï¼Œéœ€è¦æ™‚é–“é©æ‡‰æ“ä½œã€‚

  • éŠæˆ²å ´æ™¯å°‘ï¼Œè€Œä¸”ç›®æ¨™å–®ä¸€ï¼Œå¤§éƒ¨åˆ†æ™‚é–“å…¶å¯¦éƒ½æ˜¯èŠ±åœ¨å­¸ç¿’çš„éšæ®µï¼Œäº†è§£æ©Ÿåˆ¶å¾Œå°±åªå‰©ä¸‹æŒ‘æˆ°ç”Ÿå­˜æ™‚é–“ã€‚
è€å¯¦èªªé€™ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€æ¬¾å¤§çœ¾å‘çš„ç”Ÿå­˜éŠæˆ²ï¼Œç¸±ä½¿æœ‰è‘—ä¸éŒ¯çš„æ§‹æƒ³ï¼Œä½†å‹¸é€€åŠŸåŠ›ä¹Ÿæ˜¯è »é«˜çš„ï¼Œä¸éåªè¦åº¦éäº†å­¸ç¿’çš„é™£ç—›æœŸï¼Œå¾ŒæœŸå°±èƒ½äº«å—é‚£è®“äººç²¾ç¥ç·Šå´©å’Œæ‰‹å¿™è…³äº‚çš„æ¨‚è¶£ã€‚
ç”Ÿå­˜äº†å¿« 87 åˆ†é˜ï¼Œå¤©æ¢¯æ’ 283 åï¼Œæœ€å¾Œå› ç‚ºäºŒæ°§åŒ–ç¢³ç³»çµ±å…¨å£æ‰æ‰€ä»¥æ­»äº† 
Une capture d'Ã©cran de Tin Can
Par : FL

å¥½è©•ç‡ï¼šğŸŸ¢ ğŸŸ¢ ğŸŸ¢ âš« âš«ï¼ˆ5 ç‡ˆç‚ºæœ€ä½³ï¼‰
é‘‘è³å®¶ - è©•è«–æ‰­è›‹æ©Ÿ Review Gashapon
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44228872/
 
FL
618 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
12 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
7.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 14 mai 2022
// I decided to clean up my review a bit now that it's not 2am after a 6h whiskey-improved stream.

tl;dr:
fun, challenging, initially frantic game that does not explain much, may become repetitive, basically no story.

My thoughts on the game:
The learning curve on this game is (deliberately) rather high for a reason - or at least I would say it is for a reason. I will explain that at the end of this review.
There is basically no story - the space station you are on is about to explode, you grab things you think you will need and hop into the tin can - the not so well maintained escape pod - and try to survive for rescue. That's about it.
The game features 4 different modes.
- Rescue: survive for a specific time with random events, unlocking better prepared rescue pods each time you complete a milestone. Also offers a scenario editor to create your own rescue challenge.
- Challenges: survive for a specific time with specific events or settings.
- Ranking: more or less endless mode (you will die at some point) where you try to survive as long as you can and compete in the online leaderboard.
- Sandbox: does what it says on the tin (hah). It's a sandbox where you can get a better look at things, trigger events to get a feel for how to beat them.
Excluding the ranking and sandbox mode you are looking at about 6-10h to "complete" the game, with additional user-generated rescue-scenarios being available through the developers discord. (fingers crossed for steam workshop at some point)
There is a high chance you will die in the first few runs, possibly facepalming when you later realize what went wrong or why, learning the different ways on how to deal with the random events that will appear during each run.
The RNG in this game can be a bit hit or miss, with some challenges being way too easy and some feeling completely impossible.
There is also a VR mode available that is currently in beta and does not offer all the features of the desktop mode yet.
The devs are quite active in their discord, openly looking for suggestions and feedback.
I really enjoyed my time with this game so far, facepalming quite a few times
"I am such an idiot! I just realized I have two hands!" or "Wait... has this storage been here all this time?!" and I am looking forward to spending some more time in this tin can.

The game sucks at explainig things! (not really)
I see a lot of negative reviews that pan the game for not explaining a lot of the mechanics or where certain things are or how the manual is horribly designed (by today's standards).
But I can see how all of that is intentional - let me explain.
There are a lot of (not so) subtle hints as to why you will initially struggle to make things work or understand how things are supposed to work.
The tutorial explains the biggest part of that: you are the JANITOR. You are not a highly trained specialist or mechanic. You are cleaning staff.
Of course you would not know how to repair or manage systems. You were lucky that an engineer walked you through some basics because they were busy elsewhere.
But you are on a space station so you would need to have training, you'd be an astronaut, right? And the capsule would be perfectly maintained?!
Well, sure. if you look at the game from our current perspective. You'd need some training. But there are more hints to take into account.
This is a game in a fictional, past, timeline. not the future. Things have apparently progressed differently.
Why is that?
Here are the more or less obvious hints (that I found) for that:
The manual states 2015.
The displays are CRT monitors.
We have an artificial gravity generator.
The main computer is from 1998.
There is a radio-cassette player in the bunk bed...
Not sure about you but in 2015 I did not have any of my old cassettes or even a cassette player anymore nor do we have gravity generators (yet).
With that in mind it does make sense (to me) that the game does not explain every system, every feature, everything that is available to you in that tin can. It will make you figure out things on your own - just like this janitor would need to.
 
Flurry
2,048 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
8 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
1
Non recommandÃ©
13.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 22 dÃ©cembre 2023
Unfortunately, the devs ran out of money, and the game is stuck in an unpolished, unfinished state. It's not worthy of being called 1.0, nor is it worth the $20 price tag.

Among other things, they chose to make a VR port instead of working on improving the base game. For example they promised a repair rework that never materialized, because they start working on the VR port right after they promised it.

There's lots of niggling details which make the game not as fun to play as it should be. For example the random parts you get and damage to the pod can make a run significantly easier or harder, without much control from the player.

All in all, I can't reccomend this game except on deep discount. If it's going for $5 or less, pick it up, you might get some enjoyment out of it. But at its current $20 price tag, it is not worth it.
 
Streamline
1,157 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
10 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
2.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 30 octobre 2020
Produit reÃ§u gratuitement

Concept is fun.
Gameplay is good.
What more would you want from game made by single dev.
Each "run" is unique. You can encounter different threats like flying through asteroids or freezing nebula.
Your on board systems may fail and you need to quickly fix them with help of your manual. Or if you dont want to play this game alone, give your friend a PDF file and let him explain to you what each error code means.
I can see a lot of future potential this game can bring to you, maybe bigger "tin cans" that can be occupied by more than just one person (multiplayer mode).
Im recommending this game and i can only look forward for more and more updates. o7
 
Lizard
0
13 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
Non recommandÃ©
2.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 31 aout 2021
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

It's interesting. But the apocalyptic nature is a little too much.
Trying to find something that's broke after the asteroid storm and then going right into an ice storm while you're still trying to fix things? So while you're waiting for the repair module to fix the system display and now you have other stuff breaking with not enough time with repair module to fix things...
And while you're at it of stretching out space's demolition squads... How about a save game option?
Time drifting in space should be just that. TIME.
It should give you a feeling of... Am I ever going to get rescued? I've been in this tin can for months!
I like the idea, but it's built to be a "Kill the human" thing instead of more a survival type.
Now where's the food and water???

25.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 4 aout 2021
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

TheBat

Flashback to 20 seconds earlier: "oh yeah, I'll just take the battery out of oxygen to power the CO2 scrubber!"
 
Barry, Aged 63
201 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
9 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
5.6 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 8 novembre 2021
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

Tin Can is a systems simulator.

...let me try again. Tin Can is a game about rules, some clearer than others, and discovering the intricacies of that ruleset.

Tin Can is a game about making the best decision of many bad ones under pressure. (If you're lucky, about 1 ATM, but this number can vary widely.) It's about executing on those decisions in a variety of circumstances, some easy, some challenging, to complete the mind-and-body process of dealing with your problems. It's about forgetting where you put your reference manual and getting yourself killed because of it, and learning from the experience.

Tin Can is about surviving, no matter how insane the actions necessary may seem. It's about really wishing you had a 'switch to battery backup' switch while you make a mess you know you'll need to clean up in zero gravity, under emergency lighting, in just moments. And then gritting your teeth and doing it anyway, because it needs to be done.

It's about never giving up, even when the odds seem hopelessly against you. (Hope, after all, is not part of the standard equipment of the Medusa escape pod. And even the things that are seem to be optional to someone.)

I don't usually spring for Early Access games because of the uncertainty in the process and result, but I have not been more satisfied with what I have received--a license for a game, sure, but even more than that, the ability to encourage the development of the sort of game I wanted to see in the world so badly, and to know that my small contribution is going to good use.

This is the foundation of something that can be great, and I sincerely hope that you too can experience it and contribute to its construction.

What are you waiting for? Les jeux sont faits.
 
Ashen
489 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
17 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
Non recommandÃ©
1.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 9 aout 2022
Such a great premise, theme, and environment but the game design just falls flat.

I applaud the novelty of the developers and I don't mind the frantic nature of the game or the crappy pod - I'm not sure how those reviewers missed they are playing a janitor in a tin can..

My main issue with the game is that it doesn't respect your time. The developers decided to go with a few very simple systems and a terrible manual. That really limits what you can do with the game - as it stands all that happens is that you are missing parts, you *can't* know what is wrong, and you scramble into surviving. The problem is the game is really short lived if you do that.. so what did they do? They made the game really obtuse and hard to understand in the first few hours so you are forced to die and waste time again in order to MAYBE understand what you did wrong.
There is no feedback system, there is nothing pointing you in the right direction, you still havent memorized the error codes in the beginning, and for some weird reason you are forced to wait like 5 minutes until the action starts each mission(?!).

I'm sorry, I'm not interested in doing a 15-30 minute run that I will certainly fail without understanding what went wrong or knowing I need to take a specific component with me, and then have the energy to try again for another 15 still not understanding what I should do.

I also tried the challenges.. that were extremely underwhelming and disappointing. So the game is now taking one switch and moving it around? Hurray?

This had so much potential, but it needs more systems, more unusual interconnected problems that needed a logical path of analysing and solving, a clearer way to find issues, and a more linear playthrough with checkpoints in between. I still have hope for Tin can 2, but it needs to really steer away from the current design in my opinion.
 
Droiagon

6 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
0
RecommandÃ©
16.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 14 octobre 2023
I'm an industrial controls technician and I had a tough time figuring out Tin Can's repair system. It runs on absolute moon logic.

Why am I diagnosing anything without a multimeter? Why does sometimes hitting the power button work and not others even though I didn't change anything? How is anything running without a switch? Or a fuse? Why does the monitor sometimes not display anything even when it inst broken? Why would an electrical storm drain every battery? If I clean a filter by blowing on it, wouldn't that just blow all the dust back into the air again? THIS IS NOT HOW THINGS WORK.

Above all, why does my flashlight only last 30 seconds?

With my complaints out of the way it was still fun for a few hours though. I eventually managed to beat the game, but that's partially because they start to give you extra systems after you beat easier challenges. More systems mean more opportunities to fix things.
 
Max
0
8 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
70.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 24 fÃ©vrier 2021
Avis donnÃ© pendant l'accÃ¨s anticipÃ©

Tin can is very specific in what it does, but it does it well. You have one aim, don't die, but the pod that keeps you from dying to the cold of space is kinda of fragile...

The longer you survive, the more you have to sacrifice to live, you might start to tear apart the gravity systems, gut the lights, scrap batteries, all to keep the CO2 extraction system from stopping. You might want more power and heat, so you take apart part of the power core's regulation system and push extra power the the battery charging station and the CO2>O2 systems to both get you back-ups set and your oxygen secured. You need to make these choices in response to the events that plague your trip, like flying too close to a sun, blasting through an ice nebula or even skimming the gravitational pull of a Black hole. Each event needs you to react in some way to it, otherwise you will die.

The game is still in Beta, but the devs are very active in their discord, and are always willing to hear new ideas. Planned soon is fire, and that idea scares me. It scares me so much. I can't wait.
 
Hydronum
306 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
6 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
3.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 4 juillet 2022
I don't know what I expected, but I was kinda disappointed. It's clear that the game is done with love and attention, but unfortunately it's a little more than a hectic clicker game with some good and some bad ideas. The tutorial is severely lacking, and I had to search forums multiple times during gameplay. Items often fall through textures. Voice acting is very amateur and quality of recordings is bad. There isn't much to do in general, and the whole thing is about juggling the parts around a few devices, usually while panicking.

Surprisingly, I enjoyed sandbox and making my own scenario more than preset 5-30 minutes sessions. Probably because the game becomes less hectic and panic inducing with more parts, not less. Hazards are a nice touch, but you kinda wish there were dozens of them, rather than just 5.

After 3 hours, it felt like I've experienced everything the game had to offer and uninstalled.

I am giving it a thumbs up, but it's still around 60-65%% for me at the moment.
 
Celador
321 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
10 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
8.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 5 septembre 2023
Few games bring me close to hurling my mouse out of the window, but this is one of them. It's a great idea, but it's designed to **** you off in every way it can.

*BANG*
Lights go out
Klaxons blare
Gravity goes out
<insert 5 minutes of panic>
You die
Repeat.

I've played this for 8 hours, and managed to get MOST of the way through the rescue missions. When I was 28 minutes into a 25-minute mission, and with less than 30 seconds to go on the radio, I died of an overheat because the cooling thing refused to switch on despite ALL its components testing fine, AND there being a full battery and power, I decided it was time to call it a day. Too much can go wrong, and you're at the mercy of the RNG.

For the rescue missions, you just need to learn the sequence of the 'events', and prepare for them. You learn what to grab, and what to pull out at what time. They're doable with repetition. So, a 10 minute mission might actually take 1 to 2 hours because you need to play it over and over and over.

A lot of love has been put into it, but I just can't tell if screens not activating until you turn them on and off, pull out all the components and replace them is a bug, or a feature of the components jostling loose...

I really want to love this game, but it irritated me too much. I'm giving it a thumbs up because the developer did a brilliant job of this game. If you love the constant grind and repetition of these new "roguelikes", then play it.


 
Dark Blue Monkey

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 6 aout 2023
Got this from Humble Bundle Choice.

The game is fun. There is a learning curve that once you find what works for the scenarios you leaves you feeling like a NASA tech guru. From the negative reviews I have seen there are complaints that you aren't spoon fed what is wrong and that is part of the fun. Finding what works what doesn't work for each of the situations you face. Not sure on replay-ability yet since once you do the run you know how to solve it.

å°½ç®¡å…¶ä¸­æœ‰å†™æ˜äº†å¦‚ä½•åº”å¯¹å„ç§çªå‘äº‹ä»¶çš„è¯¦ç»†å¤ªç©ºèˆ±æŠ€æœ¯æ‰‹å†Œï¼Œä½†å®é™…ä¸Šå½“é—®é¢˜çœŸæ­£åˆ°æ¥çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå¤§éƒ¨åˆ†çš„ç©å®¶åœ¨å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†çš„æ—¶å€™è¿˜æ˜¯å¤„äºç´§å¼ æˆ–æ‡µé€¼çš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œç´§å¼ ä¼šå¯¼è‡´æ‰‹å¿™è„šä¹±ï¼Œä¸¥é‡çš„æ—¶å€™è¿˜ä¼šè®©äººé—å¿˜ï¼Œä½ æ‡‚çš„ã€‚å› æ­¤æˆ‘å¼ºçƒˆæ¨èåˆ¶ä½œç»„èƒ½å¤Ÿåœ¨æœªæ¥æ¨å‡ºåŒäººæ¨¡å¼ï¼ˆ3äººåŠä»¥ä¸Šå°±ç®—äº†ï¼Œæ¯”è¾ƒå¤ªç©ºèˆ±çš„ç©ºé—´æœ¬æ¥å°±æœ‰é™åˆ¶ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™æ ·ä¸ä»…èƒ½é€‚å½“åœ°é™ä½éš¾åº¦ï¼Œä¹Ÿèƒ½å¢åŠ åŒäººæ¸¸ç©æ—¶çš„æ•´æ´»è¶£å‘³ã€‚
